content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals, 10 minus, 2 y"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 0, equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate <math alttext="f of 0.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals, 10 minus, 2 y"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 0, equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the tangent line to approximate <math alttext="f of 0.5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find the value of <math alttext="the second derivative of y, with respect to x"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 2"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the graph of <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> concave up or concave down at the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 2"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(c) Find <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the particular solution to the differential equation with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 0, equals 2"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) For the particular solution <math alttext="y equals, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> found in part (c), find <math alttext="the limit as x approaches infinity, of, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 1.15: Connecting Limits at Infinity and Horizontal Asymptotes

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
